sols_html:
Simply trying to evaluate the limit as written gives the following:

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to \pi^+} \frac{\sin x}{x - \pi} = \frac{0}{0}\end{aligned}\]

This is an indeterminate form and means that we can use L’Hopital’s Rule. Differentiating the numerator and denominator of the function, we get the new limit:

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to \pi^+} \frac{\cos x}{1} = \lim_{x \to \pi^+} \cos x\end{aligned}\]

Simply evaluating this limit gives

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to \pi^+} \cos x = -1\end{aligned}\]

which is also the value of the original limit.
